objective:
Course Title: Numerical Analysis with MATLAB

Course Objectives:
This course introduces students to the fundamentals and applications of numerical methods to solve various engineering and scientific problems. By the end of the course, students will understand how to formulate mathematical models, analyze errors, solve nonlinear equations, perform matrix-based solutions of linear systems, apply curve fitting and interpolation techniques, and solve differential equations numerically. The course emphasizes practical MATLAB implementation, encouraging students to develop, test, and interpret numerical algorithms and simulations. Emphasis will also be placed on the methods' efficiency, stability, and accuracy. The course prepares students to be competent problem-solvers in real-world situations where analytical solutions are infeasible.

Teaching Methods:
The course employs a combination of lectures, hands-on MATLAB tutorials, problem-solving sessions, and project-based learning. Weekly lectures introduce theoretical foundations and derivations of algorithms, reinforced with illustrative engineering applications. Students will engage in weekly computer labs to implement and test methods in MATLAB, using provided templates or writing their scripts. Regular homework and in-class problem sets enhance analytical thinking and programming proficiency. Open discussions, collaborative projects, and quizzes provide formative feedback, while a final project allows for creative exploration of numerical methods in student-selected topics. Using graphical visualizations and case studies ensures connection to real-world phenomena, fostering theoretical understanding and practical competency.
schedule:
18-Week Course Outline

Week	Topic	MATLAB Practice/Demonstration	
=========================================

1	Introduction to Numerical Methods and Mathematical Modeling	Euler’s method on motion models

2	MATLAB Fundamentals	Vectors, matrices, scripts, and plotting

3	Programming in MATLAB	M-files, loops, conditionals, input/output

4	Round-off and Truncation Errors	Taylor series, error plots

5	Root Finding I: Bracketing Methods	Bisection & false position with error estimation	

6	Root Finding II: Open Methods	Newton-Raphson, secant, fzero

7	Optimization Methods	Golden-section search, fminbnd, fminsearch	

8	Linear Systems I: Direct Methods	Gauss elimination, LU decomposition	

9	Midterm Exam	—	—

10	Linear Systems II: Iterative Methods	Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel, fsolve

11	Matrix Properties and Conditioning	Matrix inverse, norms, condition number

12	Polynomial Interpolation	Newton, Lagrange, polyfit/polyval

13	Spline and Piecewise Interpolation	Natural, clamped, and not-a-knot cubic splines

14	Regression: Linear and Nonlinear	Linear regression, multiple regression, lsqcurvefit	

15	Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors	Polynomial method, power method, eig function	

16	Fourier Analysis	FFT, power spectrum analysis, Nyquist frequency	

17	Numerical Integration	Trapezoidal, Simpson’s, Gauss quadrature, integral	

18	Final Exam	—	—
